answer_html: Note: The differential equation is no longer valid after this time, because a negative height of fluid in a tank does not make sense.
answer_latex:
\emph{Note: The differential equation is no longer valid after this
time, because a negative height of fluid in a tank does not make sense.}
hints_html: The container is empty when the height of the fluid in the container is zero.
hints_latex:
The container is empty when the height of the fluid in the container is
zero.
hints_raw: The container is empty when the height of the fluid in the container is zero.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
To find the time tempty when the height h(tempty) is zero we calculate

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = h(t_{\text{empty}}) = \left(h_0^{2/3}- \frac23 kt_{\text{empty}}\right)^{3/2}.\end{aligned}\]

Solving for tempty yields

\[\begin{aligned} t_{\text{empty}} = \frac{3}{2k} h_0^{2/3}.\end{aligned}\]

Note: The differential equation is no longer valid after this time, because a negative height of fluid in a tank does not make sense.
sols_raw:
To find the time ''t<sub>empty</sub>'' when the height ''h(t<sub>empty</sub>)'' is zero we calculate

:<math> 0 = h(t_{\text{empty}}) = \left(h_0^{2/3}- \frac23 kt_{\text{empty}}\right)^{3/2}. </math>

Solving for ''t<sub>empty</sub>'' yields

:<math> t_{\text{empty}} = \frac{3}{2k} h_0^{2/3}. </math>


''Note: The differential equation is no longer valid after this time, because a negative height of fluid in a tank does not make sense.''
statement_html:
The height of fluid, \(h(t)\) in a cylindrical container is controlled by a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0\end{aligned}\]

where \(k>0\), \(h_0>0\) are constants, and \(h_0\) is the initial height of the fluid.

(b) At what time will the container be empty?
statement_latex:
The height of fluid, $h(t)$ in a cylindrical container is controlled by
a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation

\begin{align*}
\frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0
\end{align*} where $k>0$, $h_0>0$ are
constants, and $h_0$ is the initial height of the fluid.

(b) At what time will the container be empty?
statement_raw:
The height of fluid, <math>h(t)</math> in a cylindrical container is controlled by a pump so that it satisfies the differential equation
:<math> \frac{dh}{dt} = -kh^{1/3}, \quad h(0)=h_0 </math>
where <math>k>0</math>, <math>h_0>0</math> are constants, and <math>h_0</math> is the initial height of the fluid.

(b) At what time will the container be empty?
